3-1-1.subject: social science
3-1-1.knowledge: Nutrivine is a special microorganism that can adapt to very high temperatures and decompose toxic substances without harming the human body and releases a lot of water during the decomposition process. It costs about $100 to use. Osecss is a special microorganism that can adapt to various environments and decompose toxic substances without harming the human body. It costs about $200. Rixa is a microorganism that is afraid of high temperatures, it is harmful to humans (in case of direct contact with the body), but it can break down toxic substances and does not produce additional products during the decomposition process. The price is $80. Liaq is a special microorganism that is afraid of high temperatures, it can decompose toxic substances and is not harmful to human beings, but it can corrode metals The price for its use is 110 dollars. If you want to choose the most appropriate microorganism, you need to find the microorganism that meets the conditions first (that is, whether the object needs to contact the human body, whether it is a high temperature environment, whether it is afraid of water), and if multiple microorganisms meet the conditions then choose the cheapest one.
3-1-1.question: Please select the most appropriate microorganism that applies to the scenario below. Decomposition of potentially toxic substances in a food warehouse.
3-1-1.solution: Food warehouses must not be exposed to moisture and must eventually be consumed so they must not be harmful to the human body, and shelves in warehouses often contain metal, so Osecss is most suitable, even if it is very expensive.

3-10-1.subject: social science
3-10-1.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-1.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Sam won $100 in the lottery and that night he bought a car, which he greatly regretted the next day.
3-10-1.solution: Sam was happy because he accidentally won $100, but he bought a car too impulsively, so it's the desk effect.

3-10-2.subject: social science
3-10-2.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-2.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Annie got a good score, so she went to a restaurant for the evening and ate a big meal.
3-10-2.solution: It's not really impulsive for Annie to have a big meal after a good score, so it is not the desk effect.

3-10-3.subject: social science
3-10-3.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-3.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Annie has worked hard to get good grades, so she buys an apartment to celebrate, which she regrets greatly the next day.
3-10-3.solution: Anne is happy because she has worked hard to get good grades, and this is not an unexpected event, so it is not the desk effect.

3-10-4.subject: social science
3-10-4.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-4.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Tom is so frustrated when he trips over a rock in the road causing him to be unable to attend his appointment that he impulsively buys a car.
3-10-4.solution: Tom's impulsive behavior is not caused by pleasure, so it is not the desk effect.

3-10-5.subject: social science
3-10-5.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-5.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Annie finds her long lost necklace, so she celebrates by eating tons of food, which leads to an overdose and hospitalization.
3-10-5.solution: Annie found the long lost necklace belongs to the unexpected happy things, but eat too much into the hospital too impulsive, so belongs to the desk effect.

3-10-6.subject: social science
3-10-6.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-6.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Helen was given an unexpected gift, she was very happy so she went on a trip without preparation.
3-10-6.solution: Helen is happy because she got a gift by accident, but it is very impulsive to travel without preparation, so belongs to the desk effect.

3-10-7.subject: social science
3-10-7.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-7.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Jerry won $10 million in the lottery, so he was very happy to spend $200,000 to pay off his previous loan.
3-10-7.solution: The act of Jerry winning $10 million in the lottery and spending $100,000 to pay off the loan is not impulsive, so it is not the desk effect.

3-10-8.subject: social science
3-10-8.knowledge: The desk effect is when people do impulsive things when they feel very happy about an unexpected event.
3-10-8.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Abby accidentally finds the book of her dreams at a bookstore, so she excitedly buys it and purchases a bunch of books she can't use.
3-10-8.solution: Abby's accidental discovery of her dream book in a bookstore falls under the category of unexpected happiness. But buying a bunch of books she can't use belongs to impulsive behavior, so belongs to the desk effect.

3-10-9.question: Is the following event part of the desk effect? Kate had worked hard to pass her driving test, so she excitedly drove at 200km/s on city roads and eventually received a speeding ticket.
3-10-9.solution: The fact that Kate passed her driver's license test after a lot of hard work is not an accident, so it is not the desk effect.

3-10-10.solution: Oscar's purchase of a stock that suddenly skyrocketed falls under the category of an unexpected event that made him happy. And borrowing a large amount of money to invest without conducting research is impulsive behavior, so belongs to the desk effect.

3-11-1.subject: social science
3-11-1.knowledge: Psychologist Tom has recently proposed some new concepts of motivation. Pen motivation is the motivation that arises when people go through a failure and are motivated by fear of the consequences of that failure. Pencil motivation is the motivation that arises when people are motivated by a desire to succeed after they have gone through a failure. Eraser motivation refers to other ruler motivations that do not fall outside of pen motivation and pencil motivation. Ruler motivation refers to the kind of motivation that arouses interest in the activity itself as a result of an external stimulus.
3-11-1.question: Which of the following behaviors belong to pen motivation, pencil motivation or rubber motivation? John joined a badminton tournament to get the prize money, but he slowly discovered the fun of playing badminton. So even though he lost the match, he still kept playing badminton for fun.
3-11-1.solution: John started playing badminton for the competition, which is an external stimulus, and then discovered the pleasure of playing badminton itself, so this behavior belongs to the ruler motivation in the first place. Afterwards, although he loses the match, he still keeps playing badminton for fun rather than worrying about the consequences of failure or desiring success, so it belongs to the eraser motivation.

Eraser motivation refers to other ruler motivations that do not fall outside of pen motivation and pencil motivation. Ruler motivation refers to the kind of motivation that arouses interest in the activity itself as a result of an external stimulus.
3-11-2.question: Which of the following behaviors belong to pen motivation, pencil motivation or rubber motivation? Hani is encouraged by a friend to join a basketball tournament, and then enjoys playing basketball.
3-11-2.solution: Hani was encouraged by a friend to participate in a basketball game, which is an external stimulus; the subsequent enjoyment of playing basketball is a result of interest in the activity itself, and is therefore an eraser motivation.

3-14-1.subject: social science
3-14-1.knowledge: Allen's learning stage theory is a theory that guides the order in which subjects are studied, and it reveals how to improve students' cognitive skills across the board.Specifically, Allen's Stages of Learning Theory states that for the subjects with the best test scores, further study should be done in the subjects that correspond to the next stage of their learning (even if the previous subjects were not learned well enough or the next stage of the subject has already been learned well enough). For students who do better in literature than in math, the recommended order of stages of study is: history, literature, chemistry, geography, biology, physics, math, and general. For students who do better in math than in literature, the recommended order of stages of study is: geography, history, math, chemistry, literature, physics, biology, and general.

3-14-1.solution: John did best in geography in his exams and did better in literature than in math, so biology should be studied in the next stage.

For students who do better in math than in literature, the recommended order of stages of study is: geography, history, math, chemistry, literature, physics, biology, and general.
3-14-16.question: John's scores on this exam are as follows: Literature 62, History 83, Geography 25, Math 78, Chemistry 35, Physics 71, and Biology 93. According to Allen's learning stage theory, which subject should John study first?
3-14-16.solution: John did best in biology in his exams and did better in math than in literature, so general should be studied in the next stage.

3-15-1.subject: social science
3-15-1.knowledge: Implicit attribution refers to the tendency of people to believe that negative outcomes are due to chance factors when a negative event occurs.
3-15-1.question: Please analyze whether the following example belongs to implicit attribution. Jack thinks he didn't do well in the exam because there happened to be questions on the paper that he didn't master.
3-15-1.solution: Jack attributed the negative event of failing to do well in the exam to the chance factor of not mastering the question, so it belongs to implicit attribution.

3-15-2.knowledge: Implicit attribution refers to the tendency of people to believe that negative outcomes are due to chance factors when a negative event occurs.
3-15-2.question: Please analyze whether the following example belongs to implicit attribution. Keller believes he won the lottery due to luck.
3-15-2.solution: Because winning the lottery is not a negative event, it is not implicit attribution.

3-15-3.solution: Keller attributes the negative event of not winning the lottery to the chance factor of bad luck, so it is not implicit attribution.

3-2-1.subject: social science
3-2-1.knowledge: The Bernel Effect is when the price of a substitute increases, the demand for the good decreases instead. Substitutes are two goods that can be substituted for each other to satisfy the same consumer desire or need because of their similar function.
3-2-1.question: Is the following a Bernel Effect? When the price of wheat goes up, the demand for cars goes down.
3-2-1.solution: Wheat and cars are not substitutes, so they are not Bernel Effects.

3-2-2.knowledge: The Bernel Effect is when the price of a substitute increases, the demand for the good decreases instead. Substitutes are two goods that can be substituted for each other to satisfy the same consumer desire or need because of their similar function.
3-2-2.question: Is the following a Bernel Effect? When the price of rice rises, the demand for flour falls.
3-2-2.solution: Rice and flour are substitutes for each other, so a rise in the price of rice and a fall in the demand for flour is a Bernel Effect.

3-2-3.solution: The increase in the price of rice has increased the demand for flour, so it is not a Bernel Effect.

3-2-4.solution: Cars and tires are not substitutes, so they are not Bernel effects.

3-3-1.subject: social science
3-3-1.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.
3-3-1.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? People often buy toothbrushes when they buy toothpaste.
3-3-1.solution: No, because toothpaste and toothbrushes are for brushing your teeth, they are complementary goods.

3-3-2.subject: social science
3-3-2.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.
3-3-2.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? People tend to buy gasoline when they buy a car.
3-3-2.solution: No, because cars and gasoline are for running, they are complementary goods.

3-3-3.subject: social science
3-3-3.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.
3-3-3.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? Tom bought some coffee beans when he purchased the coffee maker.
3-3-3.solution: No, coffee makers and coffee beans are both for coffee, they are generally used together, so they are complementary goods.

3-3-4.subject: social science
3-3-4.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.
3-3-4.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? Tom is a consumer who buys books followed by some printer paper.
3-3-4.solution: Yes, books and printer paper are both office supplies; they are related but not complementary (because they are not used together to fulfill the same desire).

3-3-5.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.
3-3-5.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? Tom purchased a book and then some chicken.
3-3-5.solution: No, because chicken has a low correlation to books.

3-3-6.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? Jack purchased the flashlight and then the chicken.
3-3-6.solution: No, because flashlight has a low correlation to chicken.

3-3-8.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? Anne purchased coffee and then tea.
3-3-8.solution: Yes, coffee and tea are both refreshing drinks, so they are related and they are non-complementary goods.

3-3-9.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.

3-3-9.solution: Yes, chicken and fish are both meat, so they are related and they are non-complementary goods.

3-3-10.solution: Yes, sugar and honey are both sweeteners, so they are related and they are non-complementary goods.

3-3-12.subject: social science
3-3-12.knowledge: Quadin Theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good, they tend to buy related non-complementary goods. Complementary goods are two goods that work together to satisfy a desire.
3-3-12.question: Does the following help explain Quadin Theory? After Tom purchased the beer, he purchased some wine that had gone up in price.
3-3-12.solution: Yes, beer and wine are both alcoholic beverages, so they are related and they are non-complementary goods.

3-4-1.subject: social science
3-4-1.knowledge: Complementary Giffen Goods are a special type of Giffen Goods that are positively correlated between price and quantity demanded due to the exposure factor. Giffen Goods are commodities for which quantity demanded should have fallen when the price rose within a certain range, but instead increased. A good is something you can touch or hold in your hands. For example, a hammer is a good. A service is a job you pay someone else to do. For example, cooking food in a restaurant is a service.
3-4-1.question: More and more people are realizing the importance of pulling weeds and therefore more and more people are spending money on pulling weeds even though the price keeps climbing. Is pulling weeds a complementary Giffen good?
3-4-1.solution: Pulling weeds is something that you can pay to have someone else do, it is a service not a good and therefore not a Complementary Giffen good.

For example, a hammer is a good. A service is a job you pay someone else to do. For example, cooking food in a restaurant is a service.
3-4-2.question: Although the price of Jack's paintings continues to rise, there is a fear that it will continue to do so in the future, leading to a strong demand for Jack's paintings. Is Jack's paintings a complementary Giffen good?
3-4-2.solution: The rise in demand is not due to exposure, so it doesn't belong.

3-4-3.solution: It is a Complementary Giffen good because the increased exposure makes the price grow while the demand grows.

3-5-1.subject: social science
3-5-1.knowledge: Economists have proposed a number of new strategies for increasing returns. The contra-return strategy refers to increasing final returns by increasing output, and it is generally used when market demand is not fully satisfied. Revenue-regression strategy refers to increasing final returns by increasing the price of the product, which is generally used when there is a monopoly position or in special situations. Environmental-enhancement strategy refers to increasing final returns by means of advertising, it can be used in scenarios where awareness is not saturated. Hedgehog strategy refers to increasing the final returns by enhancing the product service and is used in scenarios where the benefits from the service outweigh the costs.
3-5-1.question: A fruit store acquires a batch of high-quality apples that are tasty but don't look good. Which of the following strategies for boosting returns is more appropriate?
3-5-1.solution: Environmental-enhancement strategy. Because apples don't look good, increasing awareness through increased advertising is important to increase sales.

3-5-2.question: A pencil factory plans to increase its revenues and after research finds that the current market demand for pencils exceeds the current supply. Which of the following strategies for boosting returns is more appropriate?
3-5-2.solution: Contra-return strategy. The strategy of increasing production is more appropriate because demand exceeds supply in the market.

3-5-3.solution: Revenue-regression strategy. Energy is limited so it is not suitable to increase production. In addition, because it is very popular, you can try to increase the price.

3-5-12.knowledge: Economists have proposed a number of new strategies for increasing returns. The contra-return strategy refers to increasing final returns by increasing output, and it is generally used when market demand is not fully satisfied. Revenue-regression strategy refers to increasing final returns by increasing the price of the product, which is generally used when there is a monopoly position or in special situations. Environmental-enhancement strategy refers to increasing final returns by means of advertising, it can be used in scenarios where awareness is not saturated. Hedgehog strategy refers to increasing the final returns by enhancing the product service and is used in scenarios where the benefits from the service outweigh the costs.
3-5-12.question: A well-known jam manufacturer wanted to increase profits and found that customers were very sensitive to the price of jam. Which of the following strategies for boosting returns is more appropriate?
3-5-12.solution: Contra-return strategy. Because the user is sensitive to the price, it is not suitable to increase the price, and the way to increase the output is more appropriate at this time.

3-6-1.subject: social science
3-6-1.knowledge: Harker's theory refers to the fact that when people buy a certain good due to a tight supply in the market, they will buy some substitute goods at the same time.Market supply constraints generally occur when people's demand is greater than the market's supply and prices cannot be adjusted in the short term. Substitutes are two goods that can be substituted for each other to satisfy the same consumer desire or need because of their similar function.
3-6-1.question: Which of the following situations demonstrates Harker's theory?
choice: The market demand for corn is 100 tons and the store stock is 90 tons, at which point Tom buys some rice after purchasing corn.
The market demand for corn is 80 tons and the store has 90 tons in stock. Tom buys corn and then buys some rice.
The demand for corn in the market is 100 tons and the store has 90 tons in stock, at which point Tom buys some pens after purchasing corn.
3-6-1.solution: The demand for corn in the market is 100 tons and the store has 90 tons in stock, at which point supply is tight, so Tom buys the substitute rice. Therefore, this option fits Hacker's theory.

3-6-2.solution: Tom bought the substitute coffee because he was worried that the reduced tea production would lead to an oversupply. Therefore, this option fits Hacker's theory.

3-7-1.subject: social science
3-7-1.knowledge: Banana-cost is a special kind of opportunity cost that refers to the lowest value counterpart given up when one needs to choose among several mutually exclusive alternatives with limited resources. In other words, if one can choose to do only one thing over a period of time. If one chooses to complete A, one has to give up the opportunity to complete B and C, where C has a lower value than B. At this point the Banana-cost is C.

3-7-1.solution: Movie tickets are of low value compared to dinner, so Banana-cost is movie tickets.

3-7-2.solution: The lowest value of the choices given up is the book, so Banana-cost is book.

3-8-1.subject: social science
3-8-1.knowledge: SUPER-supply is the idea that special choices will be made under the influence of floral scents. Specifically, at this point, people will tend to choose small-probability high-yield events over high-probability low-yield events, even though the mathematical expectation of the latter may be higher. Of course, if the mathematical expectation*2 corresponding to the high-probability low-yield event is higher than the mathematical expectation of the small-probability high-yield event, people will regain their senses and choose the high-probability low-yield thing. The mathematical expectation can be obtained by multiplying the event probability by the event payoff.
3-8-1.question: Which of the following events would one tend to choose in a scenario where flowers are scented? Event A has a 10% probability of getting $300 and Event B has an 80% probability of getting $50.
3-8-1.solution: Event A corresponds to a mathematical expectation of 10% * 300 = 30 and Event B corresponds to a mathematical expectation of 80% * 50 = 40. Although Event B has a higher mathematical expectation, it is not twice as high, so people prefer Event A.

3-9-1.subject: social science
3-9-1.knowledge: The psychologist Jack proposed a new standard of personality division. Type-Q personality tends to have the characteristics of extroversion, and is very eager to succeed, easy to be disturbed by external stimuli. Type-P personality tends to have the characteristics of extroversion, with a strong internal drive, calm and collected. Type-M personalities tend to have introverted personality traits, are easily disturbed by external stimuli, and are easily agitated.

2-10-1.subject: natural science
2-10-1.knowledge: In Misplaced Addition, the sum of the numbers is determined by first determining the number of digits between the numbers. If the digits are not equal, zero is added to the digit with the lesser number of digits until the digits of the two numbers are equal, e.g. 5812 + 82 becomes 5812 + 8200. After that, each digit of the number is added to its own place, and if the result is greater than or equal to 10, only the digits of the sum are retained to form an intermediate number X, and it is recorded which digit is greater than 10 (regarded as overflow), e.g. 5812 + 8200 becomes 3012, in which digits 1 and 2 are overflowed. Finally, X is added to all the digits that have overflowed as the result of the final misplaced addition. For example, 3012 + 1 + 2 = 3015. Overall, 5812 + 82 -> 5812 + 8200 -> 3012 + 1 + 2 = 3015

2-11-1.subject: natural science
2-11-1.knowledge: The Super Numbers game involves reordering the numbers to maximize them. 1. For each super number, each digit can be moved freely to make the number bigger. 2. For each super number, if two digits are next to each other and they are exactly 2 apart, the combination of the two digits is considered to be 99. 3. If you want to maximize a super number, you can find the numbers that are 2 apart and put them in the first place. If a number is adjacent to two numbers that are both 2 apart, choose the smaller number to match. The remaining numbers are then sorted from largest to smallest to maximize the super number.
2-11-1.question: Please adjust the following super numbers to maximize them. 865491
2-11-1.solution: First put 46 at the first place, then sort from largest to smallest to get 469851.

2-12-1.subject: natural science
2-12-1.knowledge: In Tom's country, people use a number of combination symbols in their mathematical calculations. The symbol "@" means to add two numbers and subtract 2. "$" means using the number on the right to subtract the number on the left, after which the result is multiplied by 2. In addition, the symbols "@" and "$" have the same priority and come before "+", "-" and after "*", "/". "+" indicates addition of two numbers, "-" indicates subtraction of two numbers, "*" indicates multiplication of two numbers, and "/" indicates division of two numbers.

2-13-1.subject: natural science
2-13-1.knowledge: On Jimmy's planet, the nature of some elements will change, and only ion groups with 1 unit negative charge will be stable, and other ions or molecules will undergo chemical reactions to shift in that direction. For ions that are already 1 unit negatively charged will be stable and will not react with any other element. Some common changes of atoms to ions are O to (O)-, H to (H)2+, Na to (Na)3+, C to (C)2+, Ca to (Ca)3+ Cl to (Cl)2-, S to (S)3-, Fe to (Fe)+, Br to (Br)2- and I to (I)4-. In particular, brackets are used herein to wrap atoms or groups of atoms to denote ions, with the charge state of the ion following the brackets, e.g., (C)2+ denotes a C ion with 2 positive charges.
2-13-1.question: Give the stabilized substance of the following substance on Jimmy's planet after a chemical reaction. Na reacts with O2.
2-13-1.solution: (NaO4)- is the correct answer since it matches the 1-unit negative charge and the atomic change matches the change to the electrical properties of the corresponding ion.

2-14-1.subject: natural science
2-14-1.knowledge: The Kettle Force KF is a special force that is affected by a number of factors. The specific formula is: KF = 2 * M * V * T + P * M. Where M is the mass of the object (KG), V is the speed of the object (m/s), T is the temperature of the object (℃), and P is the volume of the object (m3).

2-15-1.subject: natural science
2-15-1.knowledge: A rocket animal is a class of animals that meets the following conditions: 1. it generally weighs less than 100KG as an adult. 2. it generally lives on land. 3. it contains legs or wings. 4. it belongs to the class of mammals. A mammal is a vertebrate animal of the class Mammalia. Mammals are characterised by the presence of milk-producing mammary glands for feeding their young, a broad neocortex region of the brain, fur or hair, and three middle ear bones.
2-15-1.question: Please determine whether the following species are rocket animals? cat
2-15-1.solution: Yes, because cats are small mammals that live on land and contain 4 legs.

The balloon cat weighs about 10KG and is about 40cm long. It prefers to eat fish, and usually develops from a juvenile to an adult at the age of 7 years, and enters old age at the age of 20 years.
2-3-8.question: How many legs does an 14 month old balloon cat have?
2-3-8.solution: Juvenile balloon cats have one legs.

2-4-1.subject: natural science
2-4-1.knowledge: In sky thermodynamics, there are many new units of mass. Sol-gram is a strong unit of weight, 1 sol-gram = 0.2 kg. Bil-gram is a strong unit of weight, 1 bil-gram = 0.01 sol-gram. Tri-gram is a strong unit of weight, 1 tri-gram = 20 sol-gram. In addition,1 kg = 10 hot-ounces, 2 sup-pound = 1 kg. In general, uniform units are needed for comparisons.
2-4-1.question: Which of the following items in sky-thermodynamics has the greatest mass?
2-4-1.solution: 50 sol-gram = 10kg, 1000 bil-gram = 2kg, 25 sup-pound = 12.5kg, 120 hot-ounces = 12kg. So the answer is 25 sup-pound.

2-5-1.subject: natural science
2-5-1.knowledge: In electrical-mechanics, the amount of friction is only related to the area of contact. When the weather is rainy, the friction force increases by 1N for each additional square meter of contact area; when the weather is sunny, the friction force increases by 0.5N for each additional square meter of contact area. When the current is less than 5V, each increase of 1V voltage, the object will shrink resulting in a decrease of 1 square meter of contact area; when the current is greater than 5V, each increase of 1V voltage, the object will become larger resulting in an increase of 1 square meter of contact area; when the current is greater than or equal to 10V, the object will be expanded to the maximum, and at this time, further increase of the current can not make the object further expansion. If you want to calculate the relative magnitude of friction, using 5V as a baseline, first calculate the change in the relative contact area of each of the option objects; then combine that with the weather to calculate the change in friction.
2-5-1.question: For the same object, which of the following in electrical-mechanics has the highest friction?
choice: On a rainy day, give the object a pressure of 20 pascals and a voltage of 2V.
On a rainy day, give the object a pressure of 30 pascals and a voltage of 4V.
On a sunny day, give the object a pressure of 35 pascals and a voltage of 12V.
On a sunny day, give the object a pressure of 25 pascals and a voltage of 6V.
2-5-1.solution: The relative size of the contact area is 3, 1, 5, 1, which corresponds to an increase in friction of 3, 1, 2.5, 0.5, so the maximum friction is "On a rainy day, give the object a pressure of 20 pascals and a voltage of 2V. "

On a rainy day, give the object a pressure of 12 pascals and a voltage of 4V.
On a sunny day, give the object a pressure of 5 pascals and a voltage of 6V.
On a sunny day, give the object a pressure of 35 pascals and a voltage of 8V.
2-5-5.solution: The relative size of the contact area is 0, 1, 1, 3, which corresponds to an increase in friction of 0, 1, 0.5, 1.5, so the maximum friction is "On a sunny day, give the object a pressure of 35 pascals and a voltage of 8V."

2-5-6.subject: natural science
2-5-6.knowledge: In electrical-mechanics, the amount of friction is only related to the area of contact. When the weather is rainy, the friction force increases by 1N for each additional square meter of contact area; when the weather is sunny, the friction force increases by 0.5N for each additional square meter of contact area. When the current is less than 5V, each increase of 1V voltage, the object will shrink resulting in a decrease of 1 square meter of contact area; when the current is greater than 5V, each increase of 1V voltage, the object will become larger resulting in an increase of 1 square meter of contact area; when the current is greater than or equal to 10V, the object will be expanded to the maximum, and at this time, further increase of the current can not make the object further expansion. If you want to calculate the relative magnitude of friction, using 5V as a baseline, first calculate the change in the relative contact area of each of the option objects; then combine that with the weather to calculate the change in friction.

2-6-1.subject: natural science
2-6-1.knowledge: Ti-learned refers to those phenomena in which a trait is inherited, but then the trait is not adequately expressed due to environmental changes. Ex-inferred is a trait that is acquired through acquired activity, but which is genetically influenced making it difficult to consistently improve performance. Sup-inherited refers to a genetically acquired trait that is adequately expressed. Sup-acquired is the acquisition of a trait through acquired activity that is not inhibited by the environment. Organisms, including people, have both inherited and acquired traits. Inherited and acquired traits are gained in different ways. Inherited traits are passed down through families. Children gain these traits from their parents. Inherited traits do not need to be learned. Acquired traits are gained during a person's life. Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment.
2-6-1.question: The following characteristics fall into which of the following categories? Tom's parents have brown hair, but Tom has yellow hair.
2-6-1.solution: Hair color is classified as genetically obtained, but Tom's hair color is not fully inherited from his parents, so it is ti-learned.

Some acquired traits, such as riding a bicycle, are gained by learning. Other acquired traits, such as scars, are caused by the environment.
2-6-2.question: The following characteristics fall into which of the following categories? Most humans can sense many different smells.
2-6-2.solution: Babies do not need to learn how to smell. And there is no environmental change to indicate that the feature is not being adequately expressed, so it is sup-inherited.

2-6-3.question: The following characteristics fall into which of the following categories? Tom can put a shot, but he can't put a shot more than a kilometre away.
2-6-3.solution: Throwing a shot put is acquired through learning and the inability to throw a shot put beyond 1 kilometer is due to the structure of the human body, so the answer is ex-inferred.

2-7-1.subject: natural science
2-7-1.knowledge: The rocket dog is a new species whose body color changes depending on its weight. When its weight is less than 10KG, its color is red; when its weight is between 10KG and 20KG, its color is green; when its weight is more than 20KG, its color is blue. In addition, the rocket dog will drink a lot of water on rainy days, when its weight will become twice as much as it normally does.
2-7-1.question: Suppose a rocket dog normally weighs 12 KG. what color would that rocket dog exhibit on a rainy day?
2-7-1.solution: On a rainy day that rocket dog weight needs to be multiplied by 2, which changes it to 24KG, at which point it is blue.

2-8-1.skill: Chemical reaction under Jerry's magnetic field
2-8-1.subject: natural science
2-8-1.knowledge: In Jerry's magnetic field, some special reactions occur between substances and produce substances that are unstable under normal circumstances. KV-type compounds include two kinds of HCl and NaOH. Monomers are pure substances composed of the same element, e.g. Na, O2. If one of the reactants is a KV-type compound and the other is a monomer consisting of a single atom, a chemical reaction must occur in which the three copies of the monomer will combine one of the atoms directly with the KV-type compound, and the other two monomers will combine between the atoms, e.g., NaOH + 3Fe = NaOHFe + Fe2. If the reactant does not have a KV-type compound, a random exchange of one of the dissimilar atoms will take place between reactants, e.g., H2 + O2 = 2HO, NaCl + Fe = NaFe + Cl, CaO + H2O = CaH + HO2. When the above conditions are met, the charge properties of the individual elements will be disregarded, and thus a reaction must occur between the reactants. In all other cases, there will be no reaction between the reactants (even if they would react under normal circumstances). The products of the reaction of a compound go into an inert state and do not react with other substances.
2-8-1.question: Which of the following equations holds in Jerry's magnetic field?
2-8-1.solution: Neither N2 nor NaCl are KV-type compounds, so exchanging atoms is sufficient, so N2 + NaCl = NCl + NaN is correct.

2-8-2.solution: Neither NaCl nor Fe are KV-type compounds, so exchanging atoms is sufficient, so NaCl + Fe = FeCl + Na is correct.

2-9-1.subject: natural science
2-9-1.knowledge: Under Kevin's conditions, some special reactions occur between substances and produce substances that are unstable under normal circumstances. KV-type compounds include two kinds of HCl and NaOH. Monomers are pure substances composed of the same element, e.g., Na, O2. Compounds are pure substances composed of two or more different elements, e.g., H2O. If one of the reactants is a KV-type compound and the other is a monomers containing at least two atoms, a chemical reaction must take place in which the monomers combine one of the atoms directly with the KV-type compound, e.g., HCl + O2 = HClO + O. If one of the reactants is a KV-type compound and the other is a normal compound, then five copies of the KV-type compound will be stripped of the H's in it, and three of the H's will be combined with the normal compound, and the other two H's will make up H2, e.g., 5HCl + FeCl3 = 5Cl + FeCl3H3 + H2. When the above conditions are met, the charge properties of the individual elements will be disregarded, and thus a reaction must occur between the reactants. In all other cases, there will be no reaction between the reactants (even though the reaction would occur under normal conditions). The products of the reaction of a compound go into an inert state and do not react with other substances.

2-9-19.solution: NaOH is for KV type compound, KOH is a normal compound,then five parts of NaOH will strip the H out of it,and 3 of the H will combine with KOH, so the correct answer is: KOH + 5NaOH = 5NaO + KOHH3 + H2

2-9-20.subject: natural science
2-9-20.knowledge: Under Kevin's conditions, some special reactions occur between substances and produce substances that are unstable under normal circumstances. KV-type compounds include two kinds of HCl and NaOH. Monomers are pure substances composed of the same element, e.g., Na, O2. Compounds are pure substances composed of two or more different elements, e.g., H2O. If one of the reactants is a KV-type compound and the other is a monomers containing at least two atoms, a chemical reaction must take place in which the monomers combine one of the atoms directly with the KV-type compound, e.g., HCl + O2 = HClO + O. If one of the reactants is a KV-type compound and the other is a normal compound, then five copies of the KV-type compound will be stripped of the H's in it, and three of the H's will be combined with the normal compound, and the other two H's will make up H2, e.g., 5HCl + FeCl3 = 5Cl + FeCl3H3 + H2. When the above conditions are met, the charge properties of the individual elements will be disregarded, and thus a reaction must occur between the reactants. In all other cases, there will be no reaction between the reactants (even though the reaction would occur under normal conditions). The products of the reaction of a compound go into an inert state and do not react with other substances.
2-9-20.question: Does the following equation hold under Kevin conditions?
2-9-20.solution: NaOH is for KV type compound, NaCl is a normal compound,then five parts of NaOH will strip the H out of it,and 3 of the H will combine with NaCl, so the correct answer is: 5NaOH + NaCl = 5NaO + H2 + NaClH3

1-1-1.subject: language science
1-1-1.knowledge: A flower word is a word in which the number of the following letter is subtracted from the number of the previous letter by a difference of 3. To determine whether a word is a flower word, you can first disassemble each letter in the word, then confirm the serial number of each letter in the alphabet, and finally compare the serial number from front to back, if the second letter is 3 larger than the serial number of the first letter, then compare the third letter and the second letter, and so on, if all the letters meet the condition, the word is a flower word.
1-1-1.question: Is BEHJM a flower word?
1-1-1.solution: There is a difference of 2 between H and J, so it is not a flower word.

She would invert all the nominative personal pronouns in the text, e.g. 'I' and 'you' are inverted with each other, 'he' and 'she' are inverted with each other, 'it' and 'they' are inverted with each other, and 'we' and itself are inverted with each other. She also used the number "1" for all articles and replaced all be verbs with "BE". And, when she uses a special conjunction, she precedes it with an exclamation point (!). She would invert all the nominative personal pronouns in the text, e.g. 'I' and 'you' are inverted with each other, 'he' and 'she' are inverted with each other, 'it' and 'they' are inverted with each other, and 'we' and itself are inverted with each other. She also used the number "1" for all articles and replaced all be verbs with "BE". And, when she uses a special conjunction, she precedes it with an exclamation point (!). Common nominative personal pronouns are: it, we, he, she, they, you. Common articles are: a, an, the. Common "be" verbs: is, am, are. Special conjunctions are: and, but, or, so.
1-10-12.question: Please help Susan adapt the following text to the style of her novel. Due to the heavy rain, the football match was postponed.
choice: Due to 1 heavy rain, ! the football match BE postponed.
Due to 1 heavy rain, 1 football match WAS postponed.
Due to 1 heavy rain, 1 football match was postponed.
Due to 1 heavy rain, 1 football match BE postponed.
1-10-12.solution: By replacing the text from left to right according to the rules, the answer is: Due to 1 heavy rain, 1 football match BE postponed.

1-11-1.subject: language science
1-11-1.knowledge: In the Jack Sequence scene, there is a special alphabetical order, if the letters are located between J-Z are more forward than the letters between A-I, e.g., J is in front of A; and the letter sizes between A-I are arranged in reverse order, e.g., B is in front of A; and the letter sizes between J-Z are in normal order, e.g., J is in front of K. To determine whether a word is between leading words, the word is placed in the Jack sequence,  put them in order by their first letters. If the first letters are the same, look at the second letters. If the second letters are the same, look at the third letters, and so on. If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order. For example, be comes before bed.
1-11-1.question: In the Jack sequence scene, which word is between the guide words below? honey - hello
1-11-1.solution: Put them in the Jack sequence for comparison, high after honey and before hello.

1-12-20.subject: language science
1-12-20.knowledge: Oliver likes to write in a secret code that not only replaces all nominative personal pronouns with symbols (e.g. "I" becomes "@", "he/she" becomes "#", "it" becomes "$", "they" becomes "%", "we" becomes "*"), he would also replace the articles with their corresponding numbers (a=1, an=2, the=3). For be verbs, he will use their past tense forms (am/is=was, are/were=were). For special conjunctions, he will convert them into abbreviations (and=&, but=b, or=/, so=^). In addition, if a sentence contains two or more nominative personal pronouns, the second and all subsequent nominative personal pronouns need to be replaced with "they". Common nominative personal pronouns are: it, we, he, she, they, you. Common articles are: a, an, the. Common "be" verbs: is, am, are. Special conjunctions are: and, but, or, so. For example, "It is happy to see you." to "% is happy to see they."
1-12-20.question: Please encrypt the text below using Oliver's secret code. The museum is closed on Mondays for maintenance and cleaning.
choice: 3 museum was closed on Mondays for maintenance / cleaning.
3 museum is closed on Mondays for maintenance & cleaning.
1 museum was closed on Mondays for maintenance & cleaning.
3 museum was closed on Mondays for maintenance & cleaning.
1-12-20.solution: Follow the rule from left to right to replace, you can get the encrypted text is: 3 museum was closed on Mondays for maintenance & cleaning.

1-13-1.subject: language science
1-13-1.knowledge:
Guide words appear on each page of a novel-dictionary. They tell you the first word and last word on the page. The other words on the page come between the guide words in novel-alphabetical order. To put words in reverse-alphabetical order, put them in order by their last letters. If the last letters are the same, look at the second from the last letters. If the second from the last letters are the same, look at the third from the last letters, and so on.
If one word is shorter, and there are no more letters to compare, then the shorter word comes first in alphabetical order. For example, long comes before belong.
1-13-1.question: Which word would you find on a novel-dictionary page with the following guide words? should - word
1-13-1.solution: The last letter of wind is 'd' and the second to last letter is 'n', so wind is between the guide words and can be find on a novel-dictionary page.

1-14-1.subject: language science
1-14-1.knowledge: Hacker had his own style of greeting in letters; he believed that every word of a sentence should be of the same length, and if a word was not the longest, it should be followed by a number of '*', which were made to coincide with the length of the longest word by the addition of the '*'. And that Hacker would capitalize the first word of every letter, ending it with a comma. Proper nouns should also be capitalized. For example, 'Dear Aunt Sue*,'.
1-14-1.question: Which is the Hacker way of greeting in his letter?
1-14-1.solution: Grandpa is 7 characters, so other words need to be supplemented to 7 characters using '*' and capitalizing the first letter of the letter and the first letter of the proper noun.

1-3-1.skill: Peace sentence, fight sentence and war sentence
1-3-1.subject: language science
1-3-1.knowledge: A simple sentence is a sentence with only one subject and predicate. For, example, The pitcher threw the ball to first base. A peace sentence is a sentence that contains only one subject and predicate and the sentence is in the passive voice. For example, the task was carried out. A fight sentence is two peace sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction (e.g., and, but, or, so, because). For example, the newspaper was blackened and the books were soaked. A war sentence is a sentence that contains is two sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction (e.g., and, but, or, so, because), one of which is a peace sentence and the other is a simple sentence but not a peace sentence. For example, the leaves were green, but the apple was hidden.
1-3-1.question: Which is a war sentence?
choice: The cup was knocked over by Tom.
Tom was sad because he knocked the cup over.
Tom was sad because the cup was knocked over by him.
1-3-1.solution: The only sentence that satisfies the requirement that the sentence be made up of simple and peace sentences joined by a conjunction is Tom was sad because the cup was knocked over by him.

A fight sentence is two peace sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction (e.g., and, but, or, so, because). For example, the newspaper was blackened and the books were soaked. A war sentence is a sentence that contains is two sentences joined by a comma and a conjunction (e.g., and, but, or, so, because), one of which is a peace sentence and the other is a simple sentence but not a peace sentence. For example, the leaves were green, but the apple was hidden.
1-3-18.question: Which is a war sentence?
choice: The book was soaked in water.
The bedroom was cleaned by Jack and the books were soaked in water.
The fire was growing and the book was soaked in water.
1-3-18.solution: The only sentence that satisfies the requirement that the sentence be made up of simple and peace sentences joined by a conjunction is The fire was growing and the book was soaked in water.

1-6-1.subject: language science
1-6-1.knowledge: Keller has his own style of writing, he likes to write special conjunctions twice in a row and "be" verbs three times in a row, and capitalizes all special conjunctions and replaces the article with a Z.  Common nominative personal pronouns are: it, we, he, she, they, you. Common articles are: a, an, the. Common "be" verbs: is, am, are. Special conjunctions are: and, but, or, so.
1-6-1.question: Please rewrite the following text in Keller's writing style. It was such a nice day that Tom saw a cute cat as soon as he went outside.
choice: It was such Z nice day that Tom saw Z cute cat as soon as he went outside.
It was was such Z nice day that Tom saw Z cute cat as soon as he went outside.
It was such a nice day that Tom saw a cute cat as soon as he went outside.
It was was was such Z nice day that Tom saw Z cute cat as soon as he went outside.
